turn.text: The would have filled out the form that they eventually filled out in this case.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And taken a fingerprint.

turn.speaker: joseph_locascio
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Locascio
turn.text: Taken an index fingerprint, and allowed her to sit there until her relatives posted bond.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, the only difference... the only difference is they took her to a different station.

turn.speaker: joseph_locascio
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Locascio
turn.text: And they booked her for murder.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: No, no, I'm talking about... they said they had no... you said they had no right to bring her there in the first place on a traffic ticket.

turn.speaker: joseph_locascio
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Locascio
turn.text: I'm saying--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It wasn't a traffic ticket, it was a bench warrant.

turn.speaker: joseph_locascio
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Locascio
turn.text: --That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: And for your information, those are different animals.

turn.speaker: joseph_locascio
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Locascio
turn.text: I agree.
There's no question about that.
But what we're talking about it--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: 0 xxx.

turn.speaker: joseph_locascio
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Locascio
turn.text: --Yes, Your Honor.
But what we're saying is that she was subjected to more than just being brought down to the police headquarters.
In fact, she was brought directly to the commander of the homicide unit.

And what we're saying is that when you try to justify that on the basis that she failed to pay a parking ticket, and therefore a municipal judge issued a bench warrant, that that is unreasonable under the Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That's unreasonable?

turn.speaker: joseph_locascio
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Locascio
turn.text: That when your justification is to subject a person to these type of procedures--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: You mean when someone ignores a traffic ticket, there's nothing the State can do about it?

turn.speaker: joseph_locascio
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Locascio
turn.text: --What I meant to say was, when you subject a woman to what she was subjected to, and then you say, my justification was, there was a bench warrant, when they certainly don't follow these procedures when a bench... when they really are executing a bench warrant, that that is a violation of the Fourth Amendment.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: xxx newspapers would ask you on a bench warrant on a traffic warrant in the middle of the night?

turn.speaker: joseph_locascio
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Locascio
turn.text: There is nothing wrong with executing a bench warrant.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: xxx bench warrant on a traffic ticket.

turn.speaker: joseph_locascio
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Locascio
turn.text: And the police in this case should very well have gone out and executed in this case.
But what they--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: xxx about it.

turn.speaker: joseph_locascio
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Locascio
turn.text: --What they should have done--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Don't tell us, tell them.

turn.speaker: joseph_locascio
turn.label: Mr. Joseph Locascio
turn.text: --Well, I'm... thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Locascio.
Mr. Riederer, do you have anything more?
You have two minutes remaining.

turn.speaker: albert_a_riederer
turn.label: Mr. Albert A. Riederer
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor, thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.

With respect to the second submission of the respondent, he's indicated that it would be wrong to take someone into custody for the wrong reason, even if you had a perfectly valid reason to arrest and fingerprint.
And his reason, as stated, is that you do it for the wrong reason.
The State submits here that what that means is that part of the... that the warrant requirement of the Fourth Amendment is no longer met by having a warrant.
You've got to have a warrant plus proper and pure motivation.
And it seems to me that that flies in the face of the basic fundamental... the fundamental jurisprudence of the Fourth Amendment.
If you have a valid warrant, you ought to be able to execute the warrant without looking at the reason behind the execution of the warrant.
Furthermore, all of the things that the respondent has complained about here happened after the respondent was in custody, and after the fingerprints had already been taken.
Those fingerprints were not the fruit of an overnight detention, and they were not the fruit of any questioning on the homicide.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Can you tell us quickly why... what you have to support the proposition that the arrest was at least facially on the parking violation?

turn.speaker: albert_a_riederer
turn.label: Mr. Albert A. Riederer
turn.text: Yes, Your Honor.

The arrest was at least partially, or facially, on the arrest warrant is borne out by Officer Stewart's testimony where he testified at the hearing, seven different times, both on direct and cross-examination, that he had arrested her on the outstanding parking warrant.

In addition to which, the booking record that we have referred to also refers to the warrant as being a reason for her detention, and Officer Thomas' police report, written the same day, also refers to that same parking warrant, denominating it by number, as to one of the reasons why she was arrested.
So I think the reference if replete with references to this parking warrant at the time of the arrest; not later.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It's not clear that the Supreme Court of Missouri agreed with that, though, is it?

turn.speaker: albert_a_riederer
turn.label: Mr. Albert A. Riederer
turn.text: The Supreme Court of Missouri apparently did not agree with that.
But it seems to me that a fair reading of that opinion is--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: So that even if we agree with you on the pretextual point, the most we could do is remand to the Supreme Court of Missouri to have them make clear how they come out on the other part.
Or do you want us to make the judgment?

turn.speaker: albert_a_riederer
turn.label: Mr. Albert A. Riederer
turn.text: --I think that this Court should make the judgment, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Riederer.

turn.speaker: albert_a_riederer
turn.label: Mr. Albert A. Riederer
turn.text: Thank you, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: The case is submitted.
